appointments.soap_note:
SUBJECTIVE: The client, Leo, reports that his 2-year-old neutered French Bulldog, Noah, has been experiencing stomach problems. Noah has been vomiting frequently, about two times a day, with the vomit appearing foamy. Noah's diet consists of raw goat meat. The client also reports that Noah has been low on energy, sleeping more than usual, and is less playful. Noah has been drinking water regularly.

OBJECTIVE: Upon examination, Noah's temperature is 101. His skin and eyes appear normal. Abdominal palpation reveals a soft abdomen with no noticeable masses. Noah's BPM is approximately 25, which is within normal range.

ASSESSMENT: The veterinarian suspects gastroenteritis and stress as possible causes for Noah's symptoms, including his decreased energy levels.

PLAN: The veterinarian recommends switching Noah to a bland diet, such as chicken, for two to three days and monitoring him closely at home. A recheck is scheduled in three days. The client is advised to call immediately if Noah's vomiting increases, if he develops diarrhea, or if his lethargy worsens.
appointments.client_summary:
Dear Leo,

During Noah's visit today, we discussed your concerns about his recent stomach problems, including vomiting and decreased energy levels. Noah's physical examination, including checking his temperature, skin, eyes, and feeling his abdomen, didn't reveal anything unusual. His heart rate is normal and he's been drinking water regularly, which is a good sign.

Noah's symptoms suggest he may have gastroenteritis, which is inflammation of the stomach and intestines. This can often be caused by dietary issues and can lead to a decrease in energy levels. It's also possible that Noah is experiencing some stress, which can contribute to these symptoms.

To help Noah feel better, we're going to change his diet for a few days. Instead of his usual raw goat meat, we'd like you to feed him a bland diet, such as cooked chicken. This can be easier on his stomach and help reduce his vomiting.

It's important to monitor Noah closely at home over the next few days. If his vomiting increases, if he develops diarrhea, or if his energy levels continue to decrease, please call us immediately. We'll need to see him again in three days to check on his progress. If his symptoms have improved, we can discuss reintroducing his regular diet slowly.

We understand how worrying it can be when your pet isn't feeling well. Rest assured, we're here to help Noah get back to his playful self. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns.

Best,
Dr. VetScribe

Dear Leo,

Thank you for entrusting us with Noah's care. We look forward to seeing you and Noah in three days for his follow-up appointment.

Best regards,

[Your Name]
[Your Position]

appointments.soap_note:
SUBJECTIVE: 
The client, Amelia, reports that her dog, Buddy, has been vomiting for the past 2-3 days. She has been feeding him normally, and he has been eating kibbles and drinking water regularly. However, she notes that his energy level is somewhat low.

OBJECTIVE: 
Buddy, a 2-year-old neutered male French Bulldog weighing 15kg, has a heart rate of 101 and a BPM of 25. His abdominal examination reveals a soft abdomen with no masses.

ASSESSMENT: 
The veterinarian suspects that Buddy may be a little lethargic and possibly has gastroenteritis.

PLAN: 
The veterinarian recommends a bland diet of boiled beef and rice for 2-3 days. Amelia is to monitor Buddy closely and bring him back for a follow-up visit in a few days to assess his condition.
appointments.client_summary:
Dear Amelia,

During Buddy's visit today, we noticed that he has been vomiting for the past 2-3 days and his energy levels are a bit low. Despite this, he's been eating his regular kibble and drinking water as usual. 

Upon examination, Buddy's heart rate and breathing rate were both within normal ranges, which is a good sign. His abdomen was soft and we didn't find any unusual masses, which is also positive. 

Based on these findings, we suspect that Buddy might have gastroenteritis, which is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines. This could be the reason for his vomiting and decreased energy levels.

To help Buddy recover, we recommend switching his diet to boiled beef and rice for the next 2-3 days. This bland diet is easier on his stomach and should help alleviate his symptoms. 

It's important to keep a close eye on Buddy during this time. If his condition doesn't improve or if it worsens, please bring him back to the clinic for a follow-up visit. 

We understand that it's worrying when Buddy isn't feeling well, but please rest assured that we're doing everything we can to help him get back to his normal, playful self. 

Best regards,
Dr. VetScribe

During Muimui's dental appointment today, we performed a comprehensive oral health assessment and treatment (COHAT). This is a thorough cleaning and examination of Muimui's teeth and gums.

We found that Muimui has severe gum disease, also known as periodontal disease. This is a common condition in dogs that can cause discomfort and lead to other health problems if not treated. One of Muimui's teeth (tooth 204) was particularly affected by this disease, with significant bone loss and a deep pocket of infection. To prevent further discomfort and damage, we extracted this tooth during today's visit.

We also noticed that another tooth (tooth 208) has a moderate amount of tartar build-up and some gum inflammation. Another tooth (tooth 109) has a light amount of tartar. We'll need to keep an eye on these teeth and may need to clean them more thoroughly in the future.

One of Muimui's teeth (tooth 304) has a broken crown, which is the visible part of the tooth. This break has exposed the tooth's pulp, which can be painful and lead to infection. We'll need to extract this tooth during Muimui's next visit to prevent further problems.

We also noticed that tooth 307 is missing, which may have been lost previously due to a process called resorption. This is when the body breaks down and absorbs a tooth. It's not uncommon in dogs and isn't a cause for concern.

Several of Muimui's teeth (105, 205, 405) show signs of mild gum inflammation, and there's a heavy tartar build-up on teeth 108, 208, 308, 408. We'll need to monitor these teeth closely and may need to clean them more thoroughly in the future.

It's important to continue with regular dental care for Muimui to prevent further dental issues. This includes regular brushing at home and professional cleanings as needed. We'll provide more detailed home care instructions to help you with this.

We'll schedule a follow-up appointment to check on Muimui's progress and to extract the broken tooth. We understand that this can be a lot to take in, but please know that we're here to help and answer any questions you may have.

appointments.soap_note:
SUBJECTIVE:
Owner reports that Buddy, a 2-year-old neutered male French Bulldog, has been lethargic and low in energy. The appointment was scheduled for a wellness exam and dental prophylaxis under general anesthesia.

OBJECTIVE:
Buddy weighs 20kg. Pre-anesthetic bloodwork is normal. Oral examination reveals moderate to severe periodontal disease. Tooth 104 shows stage 2 periodontal disease with 4mm pockets and moderate gingivitis. Tooth 108 has heavy calculus accumulation with 5mm pockets. Tooth 204 shows severe mobility and 8mm pocket depth with bone loss and was extracted. Tooth 208 has a crown fracture exposing pulp and was also extracted. Lower jaw findings include: Tooth 309 with moderate calculus and 4mm pockets, Tooth 310 with early gingivitis, and Tooth 404 with severe periodontal disease, 7mm pockets, and furcation involvement - this tooth was extracted. Teeth 408 and 409 show light calculus buildup. No other significant findings in remaining dentition.

ASSESSMENT:
Buddy has moderate to severe periodontal disease. Specific teeth show varying degrees of periodontal disease, calculus accumulation, gingivitis, and bone loss. Tooth 204, 208, and 404 were extracted due to severe conditions.

PLAN:
Post-operative care includes pain management with carprofen, a soft diet for one week, and chlorhexidine rinse twice daily. A recheck is scheduled in two weeks to assess healing. The owner has been advised on a home dental care protocol, which includes daily brushing and dental chews.
appointments.client_summary:
Dear Briana,

During Buddy's wellness exam today, we focused on his oral health. We noticed that Buddy has been a bit low on energy, which can sometimes be a sign of dental issues. We performed a thorough dental cleaning under general anesthesia for his comfort.

We found that Buddy has moderate to severe gum disease. This was evident in several of his teeth, which had signs of inflammation and deep pockets between the teeth and gums. This is a common issue in pets and can cause discomfort and other health problems if not addressed.

One of his teeth (tooth 204) was very loose and had significant bone loss around it, so we decided to remove it. Another tooth (tooth 208) had a broken crown exposing the inner part of the tooth. We suggested a treatment to save the tooth, but after discussing it with you, we decided to extract it.

We also found early signs of gum disease in tooth 310, and severe gum disease in tooth 404, which we also extracted. The rest of his teeth had some tartar build-up, which we cleaned.

After the procedure, we've started Buddy on pain medication to keep him comfortable. For the next week, we recommend feeding him a soft diet to avoid discomfort while eating. We also provided a special mouth rinse to use twice daily to help keep his mouth clean and promote healing.

In two weeks, we'd like to see Buddy again to check on his healing progress. At home, it's important to continue with a dental care routine, including daily tooth brushing and dental chews, to help prevent future dental issues.

We understand that this is a lot of information to take in, and it can be concerning to hear about these issues. However, with the steps we've taken today and the ongoing care plan, Buddy is on the path to improved oral health. 

Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns.

Best,
[Your Name]
